creditline: On loan from Gary and Eve Wallinga
department: Art of Africa and the Americas
description: mask with large mouth, pointed white-painted teeth, long ear lobes, round bright eyes, and painted scar patterns on face; large headdress with tall fibrous crest down center; black metal mount
medium: Wood, plant fibers, cloth, shell, lime
text: How do you usher the soul of the dead into the Otherworld' On the island of New Ireland, part of Papua New Guinea, the community holds a malagan festival, where a dancer dons this mask depicting the spirit of the deceased. The complex festival, held several months or even years after a funeral, features feasting, the resolution of disputes, and masquerades—an attempt to maintain the social order and networks for interdependence. The mask, its eyes made from a snail’s shell, is worn atop the head such that the dancer peers out from beneath the chin.
title: Tatanua mask
